newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan Islamists censure Afghan Taleban.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan Islamists censure Afghan Taleban.

text.p: Officials of two Pakistani Islamic parties on Wednesday censured Afghanistan's radical Taleban movement for its latest decrees enforcing a purist brand of Islam after it conquered Kabul.

Both Jamaat-i-Islami party deputy leader Ghafoor Ahmed and Jamiat Ulema-i-Pakistan vice-president Shah Faridul Haq said orders barring women from education and work and from going out of their homes without the "hejab" veil, and ordering men to grow long beards, could paint a negative image of Islam.
"There is no justification to close down schools and colleges for women or restrict their education, nor to ban employment of women in offices," Ahmed told Reuters.
"In Islam there is no supression," he said. "Such extremist steps will damage the name of Islam, which embraces the concept of a welfare state and emphasises justice."
The Jamaat, the most well-organised of Pakistan's Islamic parties, sent its militants into Afghanistan to fight the Soviet occupation in the 1980s.
Ahmed urged Taleban leaders to avoid repressive measures, which he said would not help bring peace to their war-torn country.
"These decisions are made in haste," Ahmed said of Taleban's decrees after the movement's militia captured Kabul on Friday, ousting President Burhanuddin Rabbani's government.
"Education for women is as necessary as for men...while there is no fixed standard for hejab (veil)," he said.
Some of the steps taken by Taleban had damaged the name of Islam and portrayed a false picture, he said.
Ahmed said he had no sympathy for former Afghan president Najibullah, who was executed by Taleban fighters after they captured Kabul and hanged from a concrete traffic post.
But he added that the ex-president should not have been killed without a trial. "And the most important thing is that Islam does not allow the desecration of a body."
Shah Faridul Haq said he fully supported the steps taken by Taleban, but advised them to go slowly and have patience.

He said Taleban belonged to a radical Islamic school of thought where strict adherence to all Islamic rules is compulsory. "They should go slow in enforcing Islam as haste could damage the process of its implementation," he added.
"Growing the beard in Islam is obligatory but one does not become an infidel without it. It is disobedience."
